title: Barbeled houndshark
text:
The barbeled houndshark ("Leptocharias smithii") is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="ground%20shark">ground shark</a> and the only member of the <a href="family%20%28biology%29">family</a> Leptochariidae. This <a href="demersal">demersal</a> species is found in the coastal waters of the eastern <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> from <a href="Mauritania">Mauritania</a> to <a href="Angola">Angola</a>, at depths of . It favors muddy <a href="habitat">habitat</a>s, particularly around <a href="river%20mouth">river mouth</a>s. The barbeled houndshark is characterized by a very slender body, nasal barbels, long furrows at the corners of the mouth, and <a href="sexually%20dimorphic">sexually dimorphic</a> teeth. Its maximum known length is .
Likely strong-swimming and opportunistic, the barbeled houndshark has been known to ingest <a href="bony%20fish">bony fish</a>es, <a href="invertebrate">invertebrate</a>s, <a href="fish%20egg">fish egg</a>s, and even inedible objects. It is <a href="viviparous">viviparous</a> with females bearing litters of 7 young; the developing <a href="embryo">embryo</a>s are sustained via a unique globular <a href="placenta">placenta</a>l structure. The <a href="International%20Union%20for%20Conservation%20of%20Nature">International Union for Conservation of Nature</a> (IUCN) has assessed the barbeled houndshark as Vulnerable, as heavy fishing pressure occurs throughout its range and it is used for meat and <a href="leather">leather</a>.
Taxonomy and phylogeny.
The genus "Leptocharias" was coined by <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>n <a href="physician">physician</a> and <a href="zoologist">zoologist</a> Andrew Smith, without any associated species, in an 1838 "Magazine of Natural History" article by <a href="Johannes%20Peter%20M%C3%BCller">Johannes Müller</a> and <a href="Friedrich%20Gustav%20Jakob%20Henle">Friedrich Henle</a>. Müller and Henle added a species a year later in their "Systematische Beschreibung der Plagiostomen", but adopted the name "Triaenodon smithii" because they regarded "Leptocharias" as a <a href="synonym%20%28taxonomy%29">junior synonym</a> of "Triaenodon". Later authors recognized the validity of "Leptocharias", and shuffled it between the families <a href="Carcharhinidae">Carcharhinidae</a> and <a href="Triakidae">Triakidae</a> before placing it in its own family. The <a href="type%20specimen">type specimen</a> is an adult male collected off <a href="Cabinda%20Province">Cabinda Province</a>, <a href="Angola">Angola</a>.
Because of its many <a href="autapomorphy">unique characteristics</a>, the evolutionary relationships of the barbeled houndshark are difficult to resolve. A <a href="morphology%20%28biology%29">morphological</a> study by Compagno in 1988 was inconclusive on the relationship of "Leptocharias" to other <a href="Carcharhiniformes">carcharhiniform</a> families. Similarly, a <a href="molecular%20phylogenetic">molecular phylogenetic</a> study by López "et al." in 2006 found that, though "Leptocharias" certainly belonged to a <a href="Synapomorphy">derived</a> <a href="clade">clade</a> also containing the families <a href="Hemigaleidae">Hemigaleidae</a>, Triakidae, Carcharhinidae and <a href="Sphyrnidae">Sphyrnidae</a>, its position within that group changed depending on the <a href="DNA%20sequence">DNA sequence</a> and type of analysis used. <a href="Fossil">Fossil</a>ized teeth belonging to an extinct relative, "L. cretaceus", have been recovered from <a href="Late%20Cretaceous">Late Cretaceous</a> (<a href="Santonian">Santonian</a> and <a href="Campanian">Campanian</a> ages, 86–72 <a href="mya%20%28unit%29">Ma</a>) deposits in <a href="United%20Kingdom">Britain</a>.
Distribution and habitat.
The barbeled houndshark occurs along the western coast of <a href="Africa">Africa</a> from <a href="Mauritania">Mauritania</a> to northern Angola, though it may range as far north as the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. This species inhabits inshore waters deep, with temperatures of , <a href="salinity">salinities</a> of 35–36 ppt, and <a href="dissolved%20oxygen">dissolved oxygen</a> levels of 3–4 ppm. It is typically found close to the bottom over mud, particularly around <a href="river%20mouth">river mouth</a>s.
Description.
The barbeled houndshark has an extremely slender body and horizontally oval eyes equipped with internal <a href="nictitating%20membrane">nictitating membrane</a>s. A pair of tiny <a href="Spiracle%20%28vertebrates%29">spiracle</a>s is present behind the eyes. Each <a href="nostril">nostril</a> is preceded by a slender barbel. The mouth is long and strongly arched, with very long furrows at the corners extending onto both jaws. It has 46–60 upper tooth rows and 43–54 lower tooth rows; each tooth is small, with a narrow central cusp and a pair of lateral cusplets. Unusually for a shark, dental <a href="sexual%20dimorphism">sexual dimorphism</a> occurs, with the front teeth in males being greatly enlarged. The two <a href="dorsal%20fin">dorsal fin</a>s are small and about equal in size; the first is positioned between the <a href="pectoral%20fin">pectoral</a> and <a href="pelvic%20fin">pelvic fin</a>s, and the second over the <a href="anal%20fin">anal fin</a>. The dorsal margin of the <a href="caudal%20fin">caudal fin</a> is smooth and lacks a notch (precaudal pit) at its base; the lower caudal fin lobe is virtually absent. This shark is a plain light gray above and whitish below. Males and females grow up to long, respectively.
Biology and ecology.
The barbeled houndshark seems to be an active swimmer, based on its strong musculature, long tail, short trunk, and small <a href="liver">liver</a>. It feeds on a wide variety of <a href="benthic">bottom</a>- and <a href="littoral">shore-dwelling</a> organisms. <a href="Crustacean">Crustacean</a>s (including <a href="crab">crab</a>s, <a href="lobster">lobster</a>s, and <a href="shrimp">shrimp</a>) are favored prey, while small <a href="bony%20fish">bony fish</a>es (including <a href="sardine">sardine</a>s, <a href="anchovies">anchovies</a>, <a href="snake%20eel">snake eel</a>s, <a href="blennies">blennies</a>, <a href="gobies">gobies</a>, and <a href="flatfish">flatfish</a>), <a href="Skate%20%28fish%29">skate</a> and <a href="flying%20fish">flying fish</a> eggs, <a href="octopus">octopus</a>, and <a href="Porifera">sponges</a> are also eaten; miscellaneous objects such as <a href="feather">feather</a>s, <a href="vegetable">vegetable</a> scraps, and <a href="flower">flower</a>s have also been recovered from its stomach. Known <a href="parasite">parasite</a>s of this species include the <a href="copepod">copepod</a>s "Eudactylina leptochariae" and "Thamnocephalus cerebrinoxius".
The enlarged anterior teeth of male barbeled houndsharks may function in mating behaviors. This species is <a href="viviparous">viviparous</a>; once the <a href="embryo">embryo</a>s exhaust their supply of <a href="yolk">yolk</a>, they are nourished through a <a href="placenta">placenta</a>l connection formed from the depleted <a href="yolk%20sac">yolk sac</a>. Unlike any other shark, the yolk-sac placenta is globular or spherical. Off <a href="Senegal">Senegal</a>, females bear litters of seven pups around October, after a <a href="gestation%20period">gestation period</a> of at least four months. The largest <a href="fetus">fetus</a>es on record measured long, which is presumably close to the birth size. Males reach <a href="sexual%20maturity">sexual maturity</a> at long, and females at long.
Human interactions.
Harmless to humans, the barbeled houndshark is relatively common and probably of some economic importance in the <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a> region. It is <a href="bycatch">caught incidentally</a> by <a href="artisan%20fishing">artisanal</a> and <a href="commercial%20fishing">commercial fisheries</a> using hook-and-line, <a href="gillnet">fixed-bottom gillnets</a>, and <a href="bottom%20trawl">bottom trawl</a>s. When retained, the meat is sold fresh, smoked, or dried and salted, and <a href="leather">leather</a> is made from the skin. The <a href="International%20Union%20for%20Conservation%20of%20Nature">IUCN</a> has assessed the barbeled houndshark as Vulnerable, noting that fishing pressure is intense throughout its range. However, no specific fishery data are available.
